This is my first Thing! I decided to make myself a custom case for my phone as it looks a boring on its own. I made the model in Blender 2.68 - first of all producing a model of the phone, then making a shell around (the case) and then using a Boolean operation to make the interior the same shape as the phone. My phone is a Star B94m: http://unlockedphoneandroid.com/star-b94m-android-41-mtk6589-quad-core-3g-gps-45-inch-screen-120mp-camera-smart-phone-p-387.html and I couldn't find a good case anywhere online.

Diese Schutzhülle wurde für das Fritz!Fon C5 entworfen. in Verbindung mit einem Trageriemen, kann das Telefon um den Hals getragen werden. Mit einem passenden Ohrhörer kann es zum Freisprechen verwendet werden. Der Druchbruch an der Rückseite
ist für ein Gürtelclip gedacht und kann entweder mit einem Füllstück verschlossen werden oder mit einem Befestigungsteil an einen Clip befestigt werden. Es ist zwar alles fügbar aber den Gürtelclip würde ich mit einem Tropfen Epoxy-Kleber sichern.

Bitte vor der Montage die Teile anpassen. Evtl. muss minimal nachgefeilt werden, da beim Drucken sich Überstände bilden können. Zur Montage auch die Bilder anschauen. Bei der Demontage den unteren Teil am Rahme zur Seite drücken, damit die seitlichen Lautstärketasten nicht beschädigt werden. (Zusätliche Sicherung, damit das Fritz!Fon nicht unten versehentlich rausrutscht.

Gewicht Oberteil 29 g brutto, 27 g netto (ohne Stützkonstruktion)
Gewicht Unterteil 17 g brutto, 6 g netto (ohne Stützkonstruktion)

Dieses Projekt ist nur für den privaten Einsatz gedacht. Die Teile sind zur freien Verfügung und nur für den privaten Gebrauch nachzudrucken. Die Rechte für die Idee und den kommerziellen Einsatz behalte ich mir vor.

Fritz!Fon ist ein Warenzeichen der AVM (https://avm.de/)

author: BBaguley

description.text:
This evolution of my Cube Gears incorporates my new snap pin design, which is much easier to insert, snaps more robustly, and prints more reliably. Included are plates for three different gear ratios (the ratios are the numbers in the filenames).  
If you need the parts individually, you can export them with Customizer. You can also add custom embossed text to the large gears.   
UPDATE: Minor update from pin library. See Instructions for details.

I would recommend snapping the pins into the center block first, then putting the gears on. Sometimes the inside of the hole in the gears is not very strong (if you print with low infill) and the pin can break through if inserted into the gear first.   
UPDATE: You shouldn't have to worry about weak pinholes anymore. I updated the pin library and this design to incorporate small slits that fool slicers into creating internal webs for added strength.   
You should also apply some grease to the pins (I use white lithium grease, but anything should work), which makes them easier to insert and remove and makes it turn smoothly without squeaking.   
Only the pins are interchangeable between the different ratio cubes; they all have different center blocks. The larger gears go on the larger faces of the center blocks. I print these on the MakerWare medium default settings in PLA. Support is not necessary.

Download open source free Blender 3D.
Import the stl into Blender
Create your message with the Text tool
Convert the Text to Mesh (ALT C)
Extrude it to give a little depth.
Then just rotate it to the position you want and join it to the stl and save.
There are videos on Youtube showing each of these steps.

comments.text:
I've printed at least 15 of these things so far on my MakerGear M2. The new pins really do make a difference. Although I modified the STL file to round the tips on the corners so it doesn't feel so darn sharp.
General print parameters:
15% infill
2 shells
no brim/ skirt and no support (although it might be useful on the pins, they tend to dislodge during printing)
All other parameters depend on your specific printer and material
.
Make sure the first layer isn't squished or the interference will make assembly and operation difficult. File down if necessary or simply wear in.
lubrication with Vaseline oil or silicone spray- preferably something that doesn't smell
Gears will become easier to turn after wearing them in.
I like to change the filament color about 50% -75% of the way through the print to give different colored tips. Also multiple prints in different colors and mixing colors.
I wouldn't recommend scaling this down by much on an FDM printer, as the pin walls become too thin to do much good.
I'm not a big fan of the EL insignia, so i modified the model to exclude it and have text on the sides of the big gears.

comments.author: EPatt

comments.text:
Nice and interesting design. Thanks for sharing it.
I used it as a challenge for my newly built up K8200. This is my results:
Employing Kisslicer and a heated bed (50°) I printed it in PLA with 0.2mm layers (11h). The pins are more or less a curse. Screwed up the first and almost the second print (sticking problems). In the end they didn't connect the parts well enough to not fall apart. Seem to be undersized which also might be a slicing problem due to my Kisslicer profile.
After all the design doesn't seem to provide any snapping into the center part. So exact sizing and precise printing seem to be very critical. I got it solved in splitting the parts collection and reprinting just the pins using some scaling.
On review I'd suggest to split up the four parts into separate files and have the joints revised.
="thingiverse-db6e7e2b449fafc55decaa715c08590e:disqus" href="http://disqus.com/thingiverse-db6e7e2b449fafc55decaa715c08590e/owens: scaling is always possible in scaling the whole print.

No one else seems to be having this problem, and the pins definitely provide a snap into the center block (by almost a whole extra millimeter). Sometimes loose belts can cause this kind of trouble. You can export any of the parts individually from Customizer.

comments.text: Yeah, I didn't design this one to scale because I'm not confident the pins will continue to work as they get thinner. However, you can scale the pins down by reducing their default dimensions, or using input parameters related to rf1. You're welcome to experiment, I just didn't get around to testing it.

comments.text: Very nice design! We printed a couple geared hearts last week, using a version derived from your original design with pins that work better in PLA, but still aren't easy to insert. These are beautiful, come right off the printer and snap in. BTW, instead of using Customizer we loaded the file in OpenSCAD, with a couple of edits it was very simple to generate individual parts. We find that printing in plates encourages stringing between the pieces and a lot more cleanup, so we prefer to do them one at a time for something like this that ought to look good. We'll post pictures later, when the second cube is finished. . .

print_settings.Notes:: Designed for easy resizing.

description.text:
Common resizable pedestal base, suitable for any stand-up, four-legged, two legged models that don't print well directly onto the printer plate even with supports.

1) Load this pedestal base and your desired printable model into your final printer application.
2) Move this Pedestal Base to CENTER and ON SURFACE.
3) Resize the pedestal base as desired- Make sure you resize x,y and z uniquely, so you can squash it or heighten it at any percent and change the radius at a different percent. Make x and y the same change to maintain a circle.
4) Then move your actual desired printing object also to CENTER and ON SURFACE. Slow Move its "Z" property ONLY until it rises where it is still touching the pedestal, but nearly all of the model is exposed.

The base is solid core, needs no supports for the exposed overhangs.

title: Mounting a Creative Live! Cam Vista IM

description.text:
Creative Live! Cam Vista IM on the IKEA-Lack leg. The camera is connected to an OctoPi.

In the 4. picture, a shot of the camera can be seen. Picture 5-7 still provisorically to find out the ideal position (height).

„Basis1.stl“ and „Basis2.stl“ for right or left. Only one part is needed.

I have installed the camera upside down. On the OctoPi in the file /boot/octoprint.txt add or modify  the following line:
camera_usb_options="-r 640x480 -hf true -vf true"
The camera provides a maximum of 640x480 pixels.

Remove the original holder from the camera. Insert the printed holder "Ball_Kamera.stl" into the camera.
Attention please: Do not press too hard! For me the holder sits very tight.

The table legs are hollow. Use short screws. I think about 3x8mm respectively corresponding shorten.

===
Above is form google-translate (sorry for that)

camera_usb_options="-r 640x480 -hf true -vf true"

title: UPDATE 11 APRIL 2014 Frsky Taranis X9D Removable antenna adapter

description.text:
Adapter to make use of different external antennas on the Frsky Taranis X9D. V2 has a slightly larger outside hole for more clearance on some antennas like the Frsky 7db patch.  
There is now also a version supporting the Frsky rp-sma pigtail with 8,8mm thread length.

To print the adapter you need to use support material. I printed it massive using Repetier/Slic3r on my Makergear M2. This adapter need a slight mod to the lower TX case as shown in the photos (easy to do with a hacksaw and a Dremel). It is designed around a RP-SMA-fm with 11mm thread lenght like this one from ebay: http://www.ebay.com/itm/RP-SMA-female-male-pin-crimp-RG174-RG179-RG316-RG188-Cable-Connector-/160864505174?pt=US_Radio_Comm_Coaxial_Cables_Connectors&hash=item2574458d56
I used RG316 coax directly soldered to the RF-board but you can of coarse use the thinner RG178 coax (both connectors can be found separately or as precrimped pigtails).
Then there is the choice to fit an U.FL connector directly on the RF-board and use a RP-SMA pigtail with an U-FL connector in the other end (this usually has the thinner RG178 coax). In any case be very careful when desoldering the original RG178 coax so that you don't lift the center wire copper trace from the RF-board. I would say that unless you are quite skilled with the soldering iron and/or desoldering station, don't attempt this on your own; get someone qualified to do the solder-work on the RF-board. You can find some more information i this thread on Rcgroups (see post #505 and onwards, and there is also some earlier in the thread): http://www.rcgroups.com/forums/showthread.php?t=1966664&page=34 It should go without saying that by doing this mod you risk the chance to fry the rf-card on the Taranis if you power up and run the tx without an antenna fitted to the sma-connector. Don't say I didn't warn you!

comments.text: i looked at all the options for taranis on thingaverse and choose this one.  I had to be careful using the dremel on the back case but the result was awesome.  Nice tight fit that wont twist went taking the antenna off or putting int on.

description.text: There are several screwable boxes here on Thingiverse, but I wanted to make one parametric so I could play around with it more easily.

Print the STL file, and use the box. Or edit the settings in the OpenSCAD file, and make all sorts of boxes. The interesting settings are: h = height in mm
nw = number of times around that you have to screw the lid to close the box
cr = radius of circle that's wiggled around to form the shape
w = amount of wiggle. Radius of box = cr+w.
t = thickness of wall and base Edit, generate STL, print. By default it generates both top and bottom, next to each other (which works great on a Replicator). If you want to maximize size in a square print area, comment out one and leave the other to generate each half and print separately. Printing tonight, I'll upload a photo tomorrow.

This is a simple bracket for holding the bottom edge of fins onto a bottle rocket.

The bracket is designed to fit a 1.5 litre shaped coke bottle (but I suspect it will fit any bottle). Three brackets are needed, and will hold 3 fins at 120 degree intervals.

The tabs on the brackets have two holes in them, allowing various fasteners to be used to attach the fins - I used garden wire.

title: Hubsan X4 107C+ propeller guard
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A propeller guard for a Hubsan X4 107C+. Note that it will probably only fit this very specific model! There are many drones under the name of Hubsan X4 and they don't look the same.

In hindsight it could probably have been made a few grams lighter if I would have designed it to mount just below the propellers like I have (now) seen others have done. But there's at least the small benefit that you don't have to remove the props to put it on/off, which might be useful for someone, so I decided to put it up anyway.

author: mamaneu

description.text: I moved into a house with two missing knobs for sliding light switches, so I made them.

If your light switches are exactly like mine (and who knows, perhaps they're standardized), print the STL and stick the knobs on. My "prongs" were 2mm wide, 6 mm tall, and stick into the knob 12mm, and have little 'dents' to hold the knob on that are 6.5mm from the end. The knobs are 46mm wide, because that's the distance between the two light switches.
If your light switches don't match those measurements, put the measurements of your prong into the OpenSCAD script and generate your own knobs! Heck, if you have lots of knobs, add labels to them!
The script can generate knobs that are rectangular, cylinders, or spheres.The rectangular knobs are easiest to print; the other shapes require support. Print them with the hole for the prong down (that's how they're generated) so that the nicest side will be out into the room.
Apologies for the marginal photo. It's late, I'm tired. :-)

title: The Snowman
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
The Snowman is a children's picture book without words by English author Raymond Briggs, first published in 1978 by Hamish Hamilton in the U.K., and published by Random House in the U.S. that November. In Britain it was highly commended runner up for the Kate Greenaway Medal from the Library Association, recognizing the year's best children's book illustration by a British subject. In the U.S. it was named to the Lewis Carroll Shelf Award list in 1979.
This model was made to resemble the body and hat. The face is not included. Model Designed by John Yoemans.

Update: 12-12-14
Added a version where it is cut in half by the X axis. You will be able to print it larger. Update: 12-4-14
Added a repaired version of the snowman that has no open holes, so the head is closed, much easier to print, Also attached a Split by X axis. and a small Y cut for a minimized snowman, The hat might need to be thickened up but i cut it in two, its still a work in progress.

title: Rainbow Dash Cutie Mark Strap Clip

description.text:
My niece is really into My Little Pony and her favorite one is Rainbow Dash. So I thought it would be nice to make her a badge for her purse. I painted it with my wifes nail polish. My niece loved it too!  
It fits on the thin 1 inch wide strap that is commonly used on back packs and other bags. The only thing that didn't come out quite right is the inner detail on the cloud. I was tracing an actual picture when I was 3d modeling it, so I think that part was just too thin for the printer to handle. This may be fixed by editing the sketch and moving the spline points for that extrude.

print_settings.Notes:: These parts were designed using Autodesk Fusion 360.

title: Lulzbot Mini Enclosure by Printed Solid enhancements

description.text:
These parts are enhancements to the Lulzbot Mini Enclosure made by Printed Solid. The parts reduce the size of the openings in the top and right side of the enclosure thus trapping in more heat. This improves the print quality of ABS parts by reducing the possibility of part splits and warping.

The top left and right cover can be used as is to reduce the size of the opening around the filament. Alternatively, if you would like these parts to plug into each other, you can insert 3 short pieces of filament into the supplied holes. This makes it easy to remove this part when loading a new spool on the printer.

The right side cover and cover latch are glued together to form the finished part. It will snap into the opening under the filament hold bracket closing off most of the hole. This can be printed diagonally on the mini print bed.

The right side cover hold bracket can be used to hold the lower part of the left and right side enclosures in place. It's a bit more elegant than the nut and washer provided in the kit. 4 cover hold brackets are required, 2 for each side.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

I used 0.18mm layer thickness

Infill:

optional

Notes:

I found that the Lulzbot Mini Enclosure by Printed Solid is a terrific improvement when printing with ABS. I am using it in my cold 58 degree F basement and now the temperature inside the box gets up to around 90 degrees F. All my ABS split and warp problems have gone away!

I used ABS for these parts so that I could use acetone to glue the parts together. It also works very well for the latch that requires some flexing to latch into place. Choose a color to suit your preference.

Note that an enclosure is a nice improvement when printing with ABS. Other materials such as PLA may do better without an enclosure.

These parts were designed using Autodesk Fusion 360.

comments.text: Hey, did anyone else have problems printing the spheres? I couldn't get more than a 1/3 of the way up! Any tips would be great. Also, the bonds require supports, correct?
comments.author: Cameron3D

comments.text: Our chemistry students (University of Richmond) purchase model kits in organic chemistry for building these molecules.  They then take inorganic chemistry and need to buy new kits (most don't) in order to do different bonding schemes; however, they really just need the "atom centers".  Hopefully without violating intellectual property on those commercial kits, we are going to redesign and print those atom centers so students can use their kits for the new classes.  More importantly, most commercial kits cannot accommodate the new kinds of chemical structures that have been learned in the last ~20 years.

comments.text: Curved double bonds are also needed.  Great idea! Look forward to printing some.

title: Garmin Foretrex 401 quick release holder / support attache rapide

description.text:
English

My electric scooter has no speed/mileage counter and as I am not sure wheels are compatible with legacy bicycle counter sensor, I chose to use my good old Garmin Foretrex 401 which does a pretty good job.
Unfortunately the build in attachment method is really not convenient. I then decided to build a quick attach/release cradle which, with the original attachment, stays permanently on the scooter.
It actually works quite good and I am perfectly happy with it. I can now snap the GPS on my scooter in 2 seconds and remove it as quickly to put it back into my pocket when done riding.

Français

Ma trottinette électrique n'a pas de compteur de vitesse. Comme je ne suis pas sûr q'un tel compteur pour vélo soit compatible avec mes petites roues j'ai choisi de re-sortir mon bon vieux gps Garmin Foretrex 401 qui fonctionne à merveille. J'adore ce GPS!
Malheureusement, le système d'attache fourni avec n'est vraiment pas pratique pour le mettre ou l'enlever vite fait, surtout avec des gants.
J'ai donc décidé de concevoir un support ou berceau à attachement/détachement rapide qui, à l'aide du système d'origine, restera à demeure sur ma trottinette.
Ça fonctionne bien et je suis satisfait de ma création (à voir avec le temps et l'usure du PLA). Je peux maintenant installer mon GPS en moins de 2 secondes et le retirer tout aussi vite pour le ranger dans ma poche arrivé à destination.

Printer:

Dagoma Discovery 200

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

15%

Part List / Liste de pièces

You will need

  • 2x M3x30mm conic head
  • 2x M3 hex nuts; Head 6.5mm

Nuts may be a bit hard to snap in its hole but this is by design. Use a pliers to make it fit.

Vous aurez besoin de:

  • 2x Vis M3x30mmm tête conique
  • 2x écrous héxagonaux M3; Tête 6.5mm

Les écrous penvent être difficiles à insérer dans leur logement mais c'est voulu. Utilisez une pince pour les faire rentrer.

author: spore29

description.text: this was a project for my robotics class

I'm building my own printer design, and when it came time for the hotend carriage, I couldn't find anything on Thingiverse that would work with my design, and I didn't want to redesign the whole thing, so I opened up Inventor and whipped this up. It's a symmetrical design, so print two and bolt them together. As designed, it's intended to run along two horizontally-oriented 8mm steel rods using linear bearings, spaced 40mm apart. You'll need to ream out the bearing holes for a proper press fit. I'd use a 37/64" bit on a drill press, but you do you. It also has a 40mm fan mount for part cooling. I'll update this post with refined designs as I manage to model them, and pictures once everything is printed and assembled.

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Hatchbox PETG:

245 C extruder
70 C bed

Design Intent

I designed the bearing holes to print undersized, with the intention of reaming them out with a drill press for press-fitting the bearings in. The design is symmetric, so print two and bolt them together. The bolts I use to clamp the halves together are 75mm M6 bolts with nuts and washers.

ASUS 7" tablet mount for 1.75" rollcage tubing, this program is under construction as I came across a couple small issues and I will be making a couple adjustments to the program in the near future.

update 3/12/17 I had a failure on my prototype unit, the screws and nuts are too deep in the unit, this put too much loading and the plastic cracked at the thinnest point, I've updated the design to have more material between the screw head and nut, now the size of screw required is a 6-32x1.75" long where they are being used around the roolcage tubing.

Cetus 3D

title: DSLR rig mount for Luxpad with ball joint

description.text:
I bought this nice LED video light called Luxpad 22 which is really nice and cheap. To improve it I already made this barndoors (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2125573). Now I wanted to mount it on my DSLR rig. The orginal mount ist for 3/8 inch skrews or the flashlight hotshoe. At the pad itself has also a flashlight hotshoe.

I decided to create a rig mount with a ball joint to be more fexible. It consits of a hotshoe with a threaded bolt, a screw nut to thighten the hotshoe to the pad. A ball joint which is fitted to the threaded bolt of the hotshoe, and a screw nut to tighten the ball joinzt to the ball socket, which is fitted to the rig. To mount to the rig I used an M5 screw with Handle, the M5 thread is cut with a thread cutter.

The threaded bolt at the hotshoe is no standard thread. I tried to produce different threads, and figured out that my printer is not acurate enough to print them. For good results,I needed a pitch of 2.5mm/per step.

Also I had some problems with the hotshoes threaded bolt, because it ihas a very small area which has to withstand a lot of force. The first threads were very brittle. They broke right a the threaded bolts base, when a litte tension was aplied.

So I decided to print the hotshoe with a tilt of 7° degrees, with support the structure touching build plate. So the fiber allingment is aslant to the thread and wraps more then one step at once, giving it more stability. It's still a litte shaky, but it works. I think I will replace the hotshoe with a metal one, from ebay. This is reason, why this Project is still "work-in-progress".

UPDATE

I added an extra hole to the bolt in the hotshoe, you can screw in a normal 15mm wood screw. This gives the hotshoe extra stability and now, nothing will crack again ;)

author: Josle

title: ArduSnake: Arduino Modular Snake Robots Library

description.text: Ardusnake is an Arduino Library for generating easily the locomotion of modular snake robots or other modular robots. It is based on sinusoidal oscillators which drive the servos. Here you can see a video of the locomotion of a 2-module worm: www.youtube.com/watch?v=jbBX5QE6ZFk It also work for longer worms or even snakes (I will add more information about it on the future) You can find more information, examples, tutorials, pictures, etc in this wiki: http://www.iearobotics.com/wiki/index.php?title=ArduSnake:_Arduino_Modular_Snake_Robots_Library and the github repository: https://github.com/Obijuan/ArduSnake

1) Choose the modules for your modular robots. For example the repy 1.1 modules or their derivatives: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13442 2) Assembly the modules and build the robot 3) You need an Arduino board or compatible. The skymega board is arduino compatible and has been designed to be screwed on the repy 1.1 modules: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:14197 4) Use the ArduSnake library to move the robot

My friend bought a Helwan Cal 9 pistol, and the grip was like grabbing a hard plastic potato with razor blades for eyes. I revised the grip to actually work. These aren't the best fit in the world, but they DO work, and the grip feels infinitely better.
airplane

Students work with different toothed gears and design different scenarios where gears can be set up for either Torque or Speed. This is a fun and hands on activity that allows students to get a "grasp" on gear ratios.

We previously have done a section in class on Autodesk 123D Design for Education. The images represent the creation of different gears with different numbers of teeth created by the students. The images below represent the steps to create their gears.
NGSS

Students create and build a number of different sized gears and assemble them into a Simple Gear Trains.  Students get a brief overview of how to create gears in 3D modeling software and convert files for print.  Students then use their mechanism to show the differences between building a mechanism for Torque and building a mechanism for Speed.  Students count the number of teeth on the input gear and count the number of teeth on the output gear and divide the counts by each other to figure gear ratio.  Once different simple gear train mechanisms are created and gear ratios solved, students take the opportunity to set up their designs and quiz their fellow classmates.

This is set up as a 4-day lesson. The duration for each step is going to vary by your classroom set up and materials. Background and Preparation: Student have already been through a design and modeling section of class and have shown mastery in designing with 3D modeling software. Students have had some background information on different mechanisms that create torque and speed. ~Makerbot 3D Printers and filament
~Computers with modeling software
~Paper, Pencils, other note-taking materials for students Day 1 (55 min)
-Attendance, students prepare for personal notes on lesson (5 min)
-Review previous lessons on mechanisms and simple gear trains, students take notes where needed. (15 min)
-Review 3D Modeling software and how to design, students take notes where needed. (25 min)
-Teacher checking for understanding and questions from students, clean up (10 min) Day 2 (55 min)
-Attendance, review of expectations for today's lesson (5 min)
-Students begin gear designing gears on computers. Higher level students begin their printing and help others while waiting for printer. (45 min)
-Teacher checking for understanding and questions from students, clean up (5 min) Day 3 (55 min)
-Attendance, review of expectations for today's lesson (5 min)
-Students continue designing gears on computers. Finished students continue their printing and help others while waiting for printer. (45 min)
-Teacher checking for understanding and questions from students, clean up (5 min) Day 4 (55 min)
-Attendance, review of expectations for today's lesson (5 min)
-Students finish printing gears, those that have all their gears begin assembling simple gear trains. (20 min)
-Students answer mechanism and gear ratio questions.(10 min)
-Students set up their own mechanisms and have fellow students try to solve their ratios. (15 min)
-Teacher checking for understanding and questions from students, clean up (5 min)

description.text:
GotWay Msuper 18 V3 is an "Electrical Selfbalancing Unicycle". While the Version 3 of this unicycle looks more elegant than it's predecessors, it does not feature a single straight line on it's shell to mount anything to it. Hence the need for a customized mounting bracket to safely attach things like an action cam and/or additional headlight.

For maximum flexibility of things to use with this mount, I chose the GoPro clamp as attachment point (thanks to MatteoMeraldi for his GoPro spare parts collection). Besides action cams, you will find lights and many other things using this standard.

You will need a metal screw and nut (M5 size) to hold the bracket in its place. Please use very moderate force when you tighten that screw as excessive force will break the plastic. Please do not try to force an oversized screw or nut into the respective openings for the same reason.

Mounting: The little pin on the inside of the bracket needs to rest in the frontal screw hole of the Msuper's handle. Beware: mounting it will likely leave scratch marks! Please use some tissue in between to avoid that.

For 3D printing newbies: this is not as easy of a print as my Msuper V3 Mudguard (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2083438). It contains a hinge to open the bracket for mounting, which is printed in one piece. Tiny supports will provide the 0.5 mm spacing between the moving parts of the hinge. When the print is finished, those supports need to break at the right places (without braking anything else). If you are not very experienced with printing such moving parts, I suggest you print the thing in vertical orientation and keep the print speed way down for maximum precision.

Material: As with the mudguard, temperature stability may be of concern when you will be using the mount in exceptionally hot conditions. Please choose ABS (or better) for those applications. Anybody else should be fine with ordinary PLA.

UPDATE: the initially uploaded file printed fine with Cura, but parts separated after being printed with Simplify3D. Version 2 has been properly fused, but I am waiting for results of a test print.

Printer:

Micromake D1

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Both the printed hinge and the GoPro mount require fairly tight tolerances.
Consequently,

  • your printer needs accurate calibration,
  • I suggest a rather low print speed,
  • I suggest vertical orientation for printing (as set in file). At least my printer will not produce a usable hinge otherwise.

I increased wall and bottom/ceiling thickness to 3.2mm respectively 2mm, hoping for improved stability. Total filament consumption is still <50 grams.

Material: Central Europeans should be fine with ordinary PLA. Those wheeling in Death Valley, Sahara or the Outbacks may prefer ABS for temperature stability.

Screw & Nut

The mount requires an M5 screw and nut for completion.
I used a M5 x 20mm Allen screw with an ordinary M5 nut.

Working on a version that accepts one of those GoPro screws with the plastic handle...

Disclaimer

This is merely the second object ever designed by me - so I'm still in the "stupid greenhorn" category.
The only effect I can almost guarantee for: it will scratch your wheels paint and leave unmistakable marks on your handle. Other than that, I have to refuse any liability for its functionality, safety and durability. It may hop off your wheel, cause you to fall and trash your precious action cam in the process!

This is a stand for the movie accurate Arc Reactor designed by zMark, inspired by the stand designed by Matt_Black_90.

This base has the following features:

  • It has a 4 mm groove on the top to accomodate a square plexiglass cover. The base is strengthened to able the hold the weight of the cover.
  • It has a 9 × 14.5 mm hole in the back to host a switch. You can customize the Base.scad file if your switch has a different size.
  • The base has enough space below to accommodate a battery compartment for AA cells. The Battery_holder.stl file is same as the flexbatterAAx2.stl file by enif.
  • The post has a hole in the center to hide the cable.

The images here show the bezel I designed for this reactor.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I recommend printing the Base.scad upside down. In the middle of the switch hole there is a manual support to make the bridge more accurate, it can be easily removed after printing.

Note that the preview of the Base.scad file is not accurate here in Thingiverse!

(The photos I uploaded show a very poor quality print of the base, thanks to a cheap metal composite filament I used. I had serious bed and layer adhesion issues. Sorry about the quality.)

Use M3×10 screws to mount the post on top of the base, and the holder to the post.

Use hot glue to glue the battery holder to the bottom of the base, and to ensure that the switch sits firmly in its place.

The reactor simply snap fits into the ring of the Holder.stl, so if you don't have wires to the base, you can remove the reactor any time.

You can use the central hole of the Stopper.stl of the reactor to lead the wires to the base, or you can use a file to rasp some space for the wires.

author: fpvgalaxy

description.text:
You can modify your Monoprice Select Mini to swap the position of the LCD and the rotary encoder. This moves the encoder wheel to the left, outside of the path of the Y-axis bed. This makes it much easier to reach the encoder during a print, for changing temperature, or pausing for a filament color change, or whatever.

The process is simple:
Remove the knob, then LCD and encoder bezel (there are two screws under the knob that must be removed as well).
Take the plastic part that supports the LCD and encoder from the rear.
Notice how the cables pass through a slot in that part.
Cut a new slot on that part on the opposite side (like a mirror image of the current cable slot). This is so that you can insert the LCD rotated 180 degrees, which will require the new slot to allow the cables to pass.
Notice that the foam pads that back up the LCD are not all the same thickness. Rearrange them so that the LCD sits level in it's new rotated position.

UPDATE: forgot to mention you also have to cut your front panel. There is currently a rectangle for the LCD and a circle for the encoder. You need to cut the encoder side out to make a big rectangle. See photo...

Here's the catch - The LCD is not symmetric. The active area is biased towards the end away from the ribbon cable. This means that when you flip it all over in the new position, the stock bezel will hide part of the active area and will expose some inactive area.

The solution is to print my new bezel, which shifts the LCD window slightly towards the encoder to line up with the LCD's active area.

Caveat: I have printed this part but have not yet fired up my printer (still disassembled, as I am doing a LOT of mods at once).
I see no reason why this bezel would not line up perfectly, but if it doesn't, please feel free to modify and remix. I have included STEP and native Solidworks files along with the STL for full edit-ability.

I printed the bezel in the photos on my company's $20k Stratasys printer, which is why it looks rather crappy. Once I have my Mini up and running and re-calibrated, I will print a new version that looks nicer :)

And Yes, that is a Monoprice Mini in the photos - I am in the middle of a full teardown and rebuild, including the orange paint, extended bed, and Titan Extruder.

Also, I did not try this myself, but you might want to print the bezel face down if you have a glass bed, for a smooth finish on the front surface. The edges have a 1.5mmx45deg chamfer, so they should print cleanly without support when face down (and obviously no support when face-up).

Enjoy!

Yet Another Reel Holder.
I couldn't find a reel holder that was just exactly what i wanted, and since i own a printer (3D) i designed and printed my own.

This consists of two identical side things, with holes to allow the shafts to be mounted at several different spacings, and vertical holes to allow for post mounting. All holes are 8mm to fit 8mm rods. Drill them larger if you want a slide fit. I drill out the vertical holes in the top of the arm, so that it will slide onto the vertical supports, or lift off easily. Cut and fit your cross bars to suit the reels you are using. I use the holder on posts on top of my Mendel, but it will also work standing on the bench or shelf. The reel is supported on 4 608 bearings with bearing guide things http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:20032 by brnrd. Tweak the scale to get a perfect fit on your bearings! On top of my Mendel the reel holder thing is mounted on bracket thing. The bracket thing is a cross brace to get the vertical posts wide enough for my reels. It has slots to reduce internal volume and a top and bottom part. The bottom part allows the bracket to fit around the z-drive rod. This is similar but wider than the previous bracket thing i made. Note to self: Don't print things you want to photograph out of black filament!

title: Wild Spaces Base Builder Game- Terrain + basic rules V2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Five thousand years into our future and a distant planet is erupting into war. This game is designed to invoke the concepts of RTS games, with each player bringing a list of buildings to the game from which they are able to spawn units and take thier side to victory.

The rules follow a simple order of operations that should allow anyone to play quickly, but with units and terrain having effects that add a layer of depth to a mechanically simple game.

In this set of files there is:
game instructions
three types of 4x4 tiles
6 building types
rubble tiles
resource piles

This collection contains all the terrain you require to play with, but I would like to add more terrain with new effects on the board and the units around them in the future, as well as new designs for boards and already existing buildings.

If you have any ideas for improvements or changes, or have any queries, please leave a comment. Rules and updates can be found here: http://eccentricnormality.org.uk/wild-spaces-base-building-game.html

title: Pinewood Derby Trophy
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This project started out as a need for some Pinewood Derby trophies for our local church youth function. So why not put this new 3D printer to use and do something creative.

This is by no means a completed project, but thought to get started sharing it here. It is 4" wide X 1.75" deep X 4.75" tall.

I have included the Sketchup file, which was made from version 7, allowing you to modify or add embossed text as needed.

The axle for the wheel is a #6 x 1" wood screw.

Edit: 02-MAR-2017
Wheel and tire V2 is an edited version of the original wheel by willkear thanks to his sharing the original file. The V2 setup now is designed so that the tire can be printed separate from the wheel. This allows you to print the tire and Ninjaflex or another flexible TPU material, as well as printing the wheel in other colors. There are some modifications to the wheel to help with printing without support, however you may opt to use a raft for additional bed adhesion. The hub has been resized to take a M3 sockethead capscrew 16mm long with the head recessed into the hub.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

7%

Notes:

.8mm wall, top, and bottom thickness. 2 layers outer walls, and 4 layers top and bottom.

230C Hot End and 55C Bed

Material was 1.75mm PLA

.4mm nozzle

30mm/s on outer walls and 60mm/s on fill.

The object may be left as is depending on how well your prints come out, but I have opted to sand and paint the prototype.

Sand with a block with 100-150 grit sandpaper, then 220-320 to smooth out the scratches. Follow this up with a couple of coats of automotive sandable primer. Allow to dry thoroughly. Then wet sand with 400 grit wet or dry paper wet. a sink with slowly running water will keep the paper from loading up and provide a fabulously smooth surface. If you still have low spots you may need additional sanding and priming. Once your happy with the primed and sanded surface, you can hit it with your favorite color. Make the first coats light allowing some drying before shooting a heavy coat. A clear overcoat is nice to seal in the color and protect from smudging as is typical with silver, gold, or other metallic paints.

The stand was originally designed is Sketchup. I started with the base rectangular box and added the chamfer all around. Then developed the base profile for the upper portion. Extruded it, and scaled the upper profile to around 2x the lower profile. Then developed the contour from the front view to intersect the bodies to get the proper trim. This detail was then leaned rearward to get the front most wall vertical. The mount for the wheel is a truncated cone place midway up and center, which is then intersected and trimmed.

The main body is designed to give the idea of a flag, with spinning wheel fidget object. I borrowed the wheel from willkear's 1967 Shelby Cobra and enlarged by 50%

title: Bumper for DSLogic logic analyzer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATE: DSLogic had been succesfully funded by 1115%. As a result it will be shipped with a case. Hopefully the bumer I designed will still be useful to someone in the future who likes easy access to the extra pins that are broken out on the PCB. for more information about the DSLogic check out:
http://www.kickstarter.com/projects/dreamsourcelab/dslogic-multifunction-instruments-for-everyone
or
http://www.dreamsourcelab.com/ Since originally it wouldn't come with a case, I designed a bumper for it. The specifications only specify the length and width but not the thickness of the PCB. So I am calling this a work in progress until somebody gets his hands on the DSLogic and prints this bumper and tries it out. Design file included, sketchup.
STL has been checked with netfabb.
Print this with 1 extra shell and probably at least 20% infill.

This is a new version of my 'Simple Cable Reel' designed with FreeCAD. Print one of each and clip them together once cable inserted, quite self explaining. Unlike the first version, this one doesnt' need to be fixed with glue, although you still may. Dimensions are so that with the flexibility of plastic it 'should' hold together well. I printed it with the Solidoodle 2, results may of course vary, and source FreeCAD may be edited as needed. I would really appreciate feedback from anyone who prints it.

comments.text:
I have printed several of these in PLA using a MakerBot Replicator 2. (2 shells; 0.2mm; 10% fill).
They fit together well and work fine. They are extremely useful. Thanks for sharing!
